4.464: Information Received at Washington by Japanese Minister Regarding the disap- pearance and Probable Death of the queen—korean Legation Think Her Dead WASHINGTON Oct 15. —information of the formidable uprising in Korea results in in the disappearance and probable death of the queen and the landing of military forces by the United States and European powers has been received by Minister kurino of Japan from the for sign office at Tokyo It is quite sense- $donal, indicating the landing of marines by Russian the United States and probably Great Britain The latest dispatch to Minister kurino states that a force of Russian marines 40 in number has been landed Thus far they have confined themselves to guard in the Russian legation at Seoul United States marines were landed from the Yorktown to the number of 16.  Its believed also that British marines have been janded.  Besides these the Japanese have a considerable force of soldiers at Seoul who have been preserving order The dispatches cope from Tokyo and communicate the substance of dispatches received from General mudra, the Japanese envoy at Seoul They are dated from the eth to the i?$n inst It appears in these dispatches that the trouble had its incan- ion through the queens dislike of the newly organized soldiery of Korea The old soldiers had the primitive equipment of the far east but with the progress of Japanese influence in Korea two he$$el- ions of Korean troops were organized on modern methods Each battalion numb breed 600 men armed with modern weeD- ops.  They were well drilled and officered.  Tai Won Kun Leads the antiroyal Forces When the queen showed her disfavour to ward these new troops they appealed to the Tai Won Kun a powerful chief who has long been at enmity with the queen He accepted the leadership of the new troops and at the head of one battalion entered the queens palace The native soldiers fled from the palace Tho Tokyo dispatches do not state specifically what became of the queen further than that she has disappeared and cannot be located The officials are inclined to believe how every that the unofficial reports of the queens death are truo.  The Japanese government the disc patches further state has acted quickly on the reports and has appointed a come mission to inquire into the facts In the meantime it is emphatically denied that the quceen’s death if it has occurred was due to the Japanese One report is that a Japanese Sushi killed the queen This is not yet confirmed in the dispatches re ceived here The officials say that the Sushi are an (irresponsible and lawless class and that their acts cannot be laid to the Japanese people or government General muira’s reports also cover the work of Japanese troops in preserving or der These troops were stationed opposite the palace having secured this point of vantage some time since through the Kos read government They took no part in the attack on the palace but after it had occurred when tho native troops were fleeing and the new battalions were end forcing their success in capturing the palm ace the Japanese troops aided in prevent in bloodshed and disorders It is probable that some deaths occurred during the me lee Following this came the landing of United States and Russian marines and as is believed the landing of the British Prince Park Likely to Rule Korea The latest indications are that the Tai Won Kun and the king are in control of affairs at the Korean capital The king has been the nominal ruler but the queen has heretofore been recognized as the real ruler The influence of the king and the Tai Won LunaTe distinctly favorable to the Japanese At the Korean legation no word has been received from the disturbed capital The officials are much exercised and do not doubt that the queen has met her death although they are not ready to abandon hope In case official confirmation is re ceived there will be such formal ceremony as is usual on the death of a sovereign Tho legation will go into mourning but there is not likely to be a funeral services although this has been considered as a further mark of respect Recent news from Korea makes Prince DeL, lately prime minister of that count try the central figure of interest in Wash ington.  He has been here for the last law weeks and is impatiently awaiting an exp petted summons from the members of the progressive party of which he is the lead era asking him to return and resume his mission of reforming the government He is likely to be the future ruler of Korea a a a a a a i a a a

4.492: The Governor Will Prevent the corbett- Fitzsimmons Encounter at All Hazards Mexico Is Now Spoken of as the Pro spective Battleground LITTLE Rock Oct 15. —governor Clark furnished fresh evidence of his determina- ion to prevent the corbett- Fitzsimmons fight at Hot Springs or in Arkansas A telegram was sent by the governor to Brigadier General John A Taylor of For rest City of the Arkansas state guard summoning him to a conference at once The meaning of the conference is that the governor desires to acquaint himself with the available strength of the state militia 50 that he may act knowingly if the situa- ion at Hot Springs reaches a crisis where the services of the militia may be re quired.  General Taylor is expected to arrive to day and consult with the governor According to the offers contained in telegrams and letters received at the exp ecutive office Governor Clark estimates that the services of 10,000 men are at his disposal for the purpose of putting down the fight if needed These offers como from all parts of the state Clark Determined to Prevent the Fight A vigorous determination to prevent the fight is plainly discernible in the sign nificant proceedings at the executive office Indeed Governor Clark was more emphat- in than ever in saying that the fight would net be allowed to come off in Arkansas He goes so far as to say that if the affair recurs as advertised at Hot Springs he tvould resign and try to find an office that he could run The governor says Cornett and Fitzsimmons have been warned and if they now arrive at Hot Springs bent on the mission of fighting their presence in the city or county will be considered an overt act and will be treated accordingly The governor says he will do everything within the scope of his power to prevent the big mill He says that he realizes that Hot Springs is anxious to retrieve its past misfortunes and he would like to help the city but in this instance his duty is plain and he will use his utmost dili- fence and power to do what it is his duty to do He would not like to put the state to the expense of sending several compaq lies of the state militia to Hot Springs and he hopes the principals and their backers in the proposed fight together with all parties concerned or interested till not impose the necessity of ordering the militia to the scene in order to stop the fight Concluding his interview Govt eprnor Clark said he did not want to see any blood shed as a result of the pugilists’ refusal to refrain from making preparsa- tons to fight He sincerely hoped that it tvould be avoided “‘t am neither seeking nor slighting any responsibility in this matter,’’ he contin- bed ‘‘and will do my duty. ”’ When questioned in reference to the proposition to change the affair into a love contest Governor Clark said that bes could make no distinction between glove contest and a prize fight It was fight no matter what it was called

If Hrs Cornett and Hrs fitzsim- mons cannot come to this city and give such an exhibition as is provided for in our article of agreement as they now stand—a limited number of rounds with soft gloves the authorized officers being empowered to stop the exhibition if it be comes brutal—then the exhibition will surely not take place in Hot Springs The best authority at our service says that this will be no violation of the laws of the state but to make ourselves absolutely safe the citizens committee has engaged the best representatives of the legal pro session in Arkansas and they are looking diligently into the matter at this time We shall have a decision from them by to morrow and upon their advice we shall act The matter will be brought into the courts as soon as we can get itthere. 5.3: As New York attracts visitors from all parts of the world says a city letter the hotels are well patronized Some new features however are now intro diced which show how wealth and lux try can increase the cost of support Here is a Fifth avenue establishment not intended for transient guests but for boarders of the highest rank It contains no single rooms being laid out in suites of three or more The rent is $40 to $160 per week to which is added the price of board which is not less than $20 per week There are families at the Sherwood whose bill is $1,000 per month and if the reader is desirous of getting rid of his money in an elegant as well as rapid many nero he will know where to take rooms The Broadway hotels charge from $3 50 to $5 per day Other houses rent rooms by the night or week and the guests take their meals at the restaurant in the basement lovejoy, the originator of this system became famous in his day end made a fortune He charged 50 cents nightly for rooms but at present the price is $1.  In addition to this there are cheap hotels near Washington market which are always full and are making money at a very handsome rate They charge from 35 cents to 75 cents for rooms and the guests eat in the restaurants These houses attract a solid class which only seeks comfort and econ omy, and hence is willing to put up in the plebeian precincts of Washington

5.31: Charles Stewart Parnell was arrested at morrison’s Hotel in Dublin early Thursday morning on two warrants signed by Hrs Forster Chief Secretary for Ireland One warrant charges him with inciting the intimidation of tenants from paying rent justly due and the other with intimidating tenants from taking the benefit of the Land act by applying to the Land Commission to fix a fair rent Hrs Parnell was taken to kilmainham jail His arrest has created great excitement His arrest was determined on at pro longed session of the Cabinet Council at which all the members of the Council except Lord Seaborne were present Since Hrs gladstone’s speeches at Leeds some of the Ministerial journals in Long don have been saying vaguely that imp inediate executive interference was neck essay to make the Land act anything but a dead letter The arrest or Part nelly however was entirely unexpected Immediately after the close of the Cabin net Council Secretary Forster left Long don for Dublin and upon his arrival there by the morning mail at a 0'clock Thursday issued forthwith his warrants to the Dublin Detective Office Hrs Part nell was stopping at morrison’s, aud was to take a morning train from the kingsbridge station to attend the con mention of the Kildare Land and Labour League One squad of detectives folk lowed by a considerable military force went into the railway station where a crowd had gathered to see Hrs Parnell off It was thought likely that he had already boarded his train The detect times went over the train without at tracking attention and the crowd sup posed that the soldiers had been called out merely to preserve order Meanwhile under command of Detect time Superintendent mallins, six detect times went to morrison’s hotel which had been carefully watched from the time Hrs Parnell entered it last evening All were in citizens clothes superin- pendent Marlins found that Parnell was stilling bed and sent up word that he would Like to see him Hrs Parnell re turned a message that he would see the Superintendent as soon as he was dressed and presently word came down that he was ready Marlins took deteec- time Sheridan up stairs with him Hrs Parnell received them pleasantly and asked if he was to be arrested Marlins handed him one of the warrants The ink of Chief Secretary forster'3 signal sure was not yet dry Marlins suggested that Hrs Parnell go with him quietly and immediately so that there should be no chance of a disturbance All right,” said Parnell and put on his hat The two policemen escorted him to the door where a cab was wait in for bim It was then half past nine The cad was driven directly to kilmain- ham prison the other detectives follow in in another carriage Hrs Parnell was warmly welcomed by the suspects in the prison Nobody at the hotel and none of the bystanders on the street knew that Hrs Parnell was under arrest and there was no demonstration of any kind There was a good deal of excited map$, however over the news when it became known and the newspaper offices were besieged On the chance of a disturbance the entire garrison of the city is in barracks held ready to march atany moment It was reported that the arrest of Parnell was only a prelimi- nary to still more vigorous action against the Land League The Secret try of the League was interviewed shortly after the arrest He expressed much astonishment at it and exclaimed Tet them come on we are ready for them!” Father sheehy, Patrick BEgan and v.  By Dillon went to Paris to-day.  It is believed that parrell’s speech at Wexford Sunday furnished the Govern ment’s technical justification for his are rest which the Moderate Liberals and the Conservatives approved The Land League Executive held a long session Thursday at morrison’s, messrs.  John Dillon Arthur o’connor and A My Sullivan members of parlia- map$, were present Hrs Dillon made a fiery speech and it was proposed that the League should issue an address It is said that Hrs Dillon who is My Pm for Tipperary will assume the Presidency of the League Hrs Dillon said at the meeting that it was the most trying and critical moment in ireland’s history for a century The statement that Hrs Parnell had intimi- dated the people was false He denied anybody to point toasingle speech of Hrs Parnell in favor of intimidation His arrest was due to private malice It was the duty of the nation to deal with the matter coolly and with judgment and to maintain the struggle within the law An additional guard and two nine pounders have been stationed in the upper Castle yard The guard at Kill mainham jail has been doubled At a meeting of the North Dublin Board of Guardians Hrs Kenny the medical officer and medical attendant upon the suspects in kilmainham jail stated that he feared Hrs Kettle the suspect was threatened with spinal disease and that there could not be the slightest doubt that Hrs Kettles syraptoms were due to his confinemevt.  Hrs Kenny added that he had reported to the Government on the subject The inhabitants of lismore closed their shops on the reception of the news of Hrs parnell’s arrest

7.215: Sunday evening about 7:30 a small blaze was discovered in Go We Milf let'3 stable on South Second The building was old and dry and in a minute was enveloped in flames and anoLe.
